required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Pain With Radiesse® With Lidocaine for Nasolabial Folds
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Pain With the Use of Radiesse® With Lidocaine for the Treatment of Nasolabial Folds

brief_summary.textblock: To assess pain during nasolabial fold treatment using Radiesse® Injectable Dermal Filler with lidocaine

detailed_description.textblock: To assess pain immediately after nasolabial fold treatment with Radiesse® Injectable Dermal Filler with lidocaine in one nasolabial fold compared to Radiesse® Injectable Dermal Filler without lidocaine in the contralateral nasolabial fold

primary_outcome.measure: Pain Score Using a 10-cm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for Pain (0 = no Pain, 10 = Very Severe Pain)
primary_outcome.description: Assessment of whether a statistically significant reduction in pain score in the Radiesse® Mixed with Lidocaine nasolabial fold was observed when compared to the Radiesse® without Lidocaine nasolabial fold using a 10-cm visual analog pain scale (0 = no pain, 10 = very severe pain). In the study protocol, the assessment of achieving a statistically significant reduction in pain at time zero was selected a priori to be analyzed using a paired t-test to test the null hypothesis that the mean of the differences in VAS scores between the Treatment and Control folds is equal to zero.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With a Clinically Meaningful Reduction in Pain As Defined by a ≥ 2.0-cm Reduction in VAS
secondary_outcome.description: In this split-face study, a clinically meaningful difference in pain was defined as a 2-cm "reduction" (i.e., subject reports at least 2-cm less pain on a 10-cm VAS) in the Radiesse® Mixed with Lidocaine NLF when compared to the Radiesse® without Lidocaine NLF.

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) Pain Score 15 Minutes Post Injection
secondary_outcome.description: A 10-cm VAS (with 21 total circles, marked at 0.5 cm intervals) was used in which 0 = no pain and 10 = very severe pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) Pain Score 30 Minutes Post Injection
secondary_outcome.description: A 10-cm VAS (with 21 total circles, marked at 0.5 cm intervals) was used in which 0 = no pain and 10 = very severe pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) Pain Score 45 Minutes Post Injection
secondary_outcome.description: A 10-cm VAS (with 21 total circles, marked at 0.5 cm intervals) was used in which 0 = no pain and 10 = very severe pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) Pain Score 60 Minutes Post Injection
secondary_outcome.description: A 10-cm VAS (with 21 total circles, marked at 0.5 cm intervals) was used in which 0 = no pain and 10 = very severe pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) Pain Score 1 Week Post Injection
secondary_outcome.description: A 10-cm VAS (with 21 total circles, marked at 0.5 cm intervals) was used in which 0 = no pain and 10 = very severe pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) Pain Score 2 Weeks Post Injection
secondary_outcome.description: A 10-cm VAS (with 21 total circles, marked at 0.5 cm intervals) was used in which 0 = no pain and 10 = very severe pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) Pain Score 4 Weeks Post Injection
secondary_outcome.description: A 10-cm VAS (with 21 total circles, marked at 0.5 cm intervals) was used in which 0 = no pain and 10 = very severe pain.

2 questions were asked of 101 subjects: 1) Was one treatment less painful than the other? and 2) Was the difference in pain levels significant enough to affect your preference for one treatment over the other? Only those participants responding "yes" to these 2 questions about pain and preference for treatment are reported in the table below.

arm_group.description: Injectable Dermal Filler. The same participants received the experimental device and the active comparator device at the same time (left and right sides of face).
Injectable Dermal Filler. The same participants received the experimental device and the active comparator device at the same time (left and right sides of face).

intervention.intervention_name: Radiesse® Injectable Dermal Filler with Lidocaine
intervention.description: Calcium hydroxylapatite particles suspended in an aqueous-based gel carrier with 3% lidocaine hydrochloride (HCl)

intervention.intervention_name: Radiesse® Injectable Dermal Filler without Lidocaine
intervention.description: Calcium hydroxylapatite particles suspended in an aqueous-based gel carrier without 3% lidocaine hydrochloride (HCl)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Is at least 18 years of age
- Is a candidate for nasolabial fold treatment using Radiesse
- Has approximately symmetrical nasolabial folds
- Understands and accepts the obligation not to receive any other facial procedures in the lower half of the face for 1 month
Exclusion Criteria:
- Has received any type of treatment or procedures including surgery in the nasolabial folds
- Has received neurotoxin, hyaluronic acid, calcium hydroxylapatite (CaHA) or collagen injections in the lower half of the face within past 6 months
- Has received polylactic acid, polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA), silicone or any other permanent filler in the lower half of the face
- Has nasolabial folds that are too severe to be corrected in one treatment session
- Has any history of hypersensitivity to lidocaine or anesthetics of the amide type

results_reference.citation: Schachter D, Bertucci V, Solish N. Calcium Hydroxylapatite With Integral Lidocaine Provides Improved Pain Control for the Correction of Nasolabial Folds. J Drugs Dermatol. 2016 Aug 1;15(8):1005-10.

clinical_study.keyword: Moderate to severe wrinkles and folds such as nasolabial folds

group.title: Radiesse® Mixed With Lidocaine and Radiesse® Without Lidocaine
group.description: Injectable Dermal Filler. The same 102 participants received the experimental device and the active comparator device at the same time (left and right sides of face). Calcium hydroxylapatite particles suspended in an aqueous-based gel carrier containing 3% lidocaine hydrochloride (HCl) and Calcium hydroxylapatite particles suspended in an aqueous-based gel carrier without 3% lidocaine hydrochloride (HCl)

participants_list.participants: One subject's treatment fold not injected due to adverse event during control fold injection

group.title: Radiesse® Mixed With Lidocaine and Radiesse® Without Lidocaine
group.description: Injectable Dermal Filler. The same 102 participants received the experimental device and the active comparator device at the same time (left and right sides of face). Calcium hydroxylapatite particles suspended in an aqueous-based gel carrier containing 3% lidocaine hydrochloride (HCl) and Calcium hydroxylapatite particles suspended in an aqueous-based gel carrier without 3% lidocaine hydrochloride (HCl)

measure.title: Fitzpatrick Skin Type
measure.description: The Fitzpatrick Skin Types (FST) represent a standard classification of skin color based on one's response to sun exposure (i.e., burns or tans), rather than defined by race or ethnicity. All FST were eligible for participation in the current study. See full FST descriptions in Astner S, Anderson RR. Skin phototypes 2003. J Invest Dermatol. 2004 Feb;122(2):xxx-xxxi.

class.title: II: burns easily, tans minimally with difficulty
III: burns moderately, tans moderately & uniformly
IV: burns minimally, tans moderately & easily

outcome.title: Pain Score Using a 10-cm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for Pain (0 = no Pain, 10 = Very Severe Pain)
outcome.description: Assessment of whether a statistically significant reduction in pain score in the Radiesse® Mixed with Lidocaine nasolabial fold was observed when compared to the Radiesse® without Lidocaine nasolabial fold using a 10-cm visual analog pain scale (0 = no pain, 10 = very severe pain). In the study protocol, the assessment of achieving a statistically significant reduction in pain at time zero was selected a priori to be analyzed using a paired t-test to test the null hypothesis that the mean of the differences in VAS scores between the Treatment and Control folds is equal to zero.

group.title: Radiesse® Mixed With Lidocaine
group.description: Injectable Dermal Filler. The same participants received the experimental device and the active comparator device at the same time (left and right sides of face). Calcium hydroxylapatite particles suspended in an aqueous-based gel carrier containing 3% lidocaine hydrochloride (HCl)

group.title: Radiesse® Without Lidocaine
group.description: Injectable Dermal Filler. The same participants received the experimental device and the active comparator device at the same time (left and right sides of face). Calcium hydroxylapatite particles suspended in an aqueous-based gel carrier without 3% lidocaine hydrochloride (HCl)

measure.title: Pain Score Using a 10-cm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for Pain (0 = no Pain, 10 = Very Severe Pain)
measure.description: Assessment of whether a statistically significant reduction in pain score in the Radiesse® Mixed with Lidocaine nasolabial fold was observed when compared to the Radiesse® without Lidocaine nasolabial fold using a 10-cm visual analog pain scale (0 = no pain, 10 = very severe pain). In the study protocol, the assessment of achieving a statistically significant reduction in pain at time zero was selected a priori to be analyzed using a paired t-test to test the null hypothesis that the mean of the differences in VAS scores between the Treatment and Control folds is equal to zero.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With a Clinically Meaningful Reduction in Pain As Defined by a ≥ 2.0-cm Reduction in VAS
outcome.description: In this split-face study, a clinically meaningful difference in pain was defined as a 2-cm "reduction" (i.e., subject reports at least 2-cm less pain on a 10-cm VAS) in the Radiesse® Mixed with Lidocaine NLF when compared to the Radiesse® without Lidocaine NLF.
outcome.population: In this split-face study, participants received both treatments (i.e., 1 NLF with Radiesse Mixed with Lidocaine and 1 NLF with Radiesse without Lidocaine). Results are presented as the number of participants reporting at least a 2-cm lower pain VAS score in the Radiesse Mixed with Lidocaine NLF when compared to the Radiesse without Lidocaine NLF.

group.title: Radiesse® Mixed With Lidocaine and Radiesse® Without Lidocaine
group.description: Injectable Dermal Filler. The same participants received the experimental device and the active comparator device at the same time (left and right sides of face). Calcium hydroxylapatite particles suspended in an aqueous-based gel carrier containing 3% lidocaine hydrochloride (HCl) and calcium hydroxylapatite particles suspended in an aqueous-based gel carrier without 3% lidocaine hydrochloride (HCl)

measure.title: Number of Participants With a Clinically Meaningful Reduction in Pain As Defined by a ≥ 2.0-cm Reduction in VAS
measure.description: In this split-face study, a clinically meaningful difference in pain was defined as a 2-cm "reduction" (i.e., subject reports at least 2-cm less pain on a 10-cm VAS) in the Radiesse® Mixed with Lidocaine NLF when compared to the Radiesse® without Lidocaine NLF.
measure.population: In this split-face study, participants received both treatments (i.e., 1 NLF with Radiesse Mixed with Lidocaine and 1 NLF with Radiesse without Lidocaine). Results are presented as the number of participants reporting at least a 2-cm lower pain VAS score in the Radiesse Mixed with Lidocaine NLF when compared to the Radiesse without Lidocaine NLF.

analysis.groups_desc: 91 (90.1%) of 101 subjects had a ≥ 2.0 cm lower VAS Score in treatment versus control NLF at Time 0
analysis.p_value_desc: Binomial proportion, two-sided Fisher’s exact test

outcome.title: Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) Pain Score 15 Minutes Post Injection
outcome.description: A 10-cm VAS (with 21 total circles, marked at 0.5 cm intervals) was used in which 0 = no pain and 10 = very severe pain.
outcome.population: One subject did not receive treatment in the Radiesse® Mixed with Lidocaine (treatment) fold due to adverse event during injection of the Radiesse® without Lidocaine (control) nasolabial fold, which was randomized to be treated first. This subject was followed through the end of the trial for safety, but was excluded from comparative analyses.

outcome.title: Assess Subject Preference to Pain
outcome.description: 2 questions were asked of 101 subjects: 1) Was one treatment less painful than the other? and 2) Was the difference in pain levels significant enough to affect your preference for one treatment over the other? Only those participants responding "yes" to these 2 questions about pain and preference for treatment are reported in the table below.

group.title: Radiesse® Mixed With Lidocaine and Radiesse® Without Lidocaine
group.description: Injectable Dermal Filler. The same participants received the experimental device and the active comparator device at the same time (left and right sides of face). Calcium hydroxylapatite particles suspended in an aqueous-based gel carrier containing 3% lidocaine hydrochloride (HCl) and without 3% lidocaine hydrochloride (HCl)

measure.title: Assess Subject Preference to Pain
measure.description: 2 questions were asked of 101 subjects: 1) Was one treatment less painful than the other? and 2) Was the difference in pain levels significant enough to affect your preference for one treatment over the other? Only those participants responding "yes" to these 2 questions about pain and preference for treatment are reported in the table below.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
